html:
Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈkan.toː/, [ˈkan̪.t̪oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈkan.to/, [ˈkan̪.t̪ɔ]

Etymology 1[edit]

From canō (“I sing”) +‎ -tō (frequentative suffix).

Verb[edit]

cantō (present infinitive cantāre, perfect active cantāvī, supine cantātum); first conjugation

  1. I sing (all senses)
  2. I enchant, or call forth by charms
Usage notes[edit]

The sense of cantō essentially coincides with that of canō with the additional possible sense of the practice of charms or enchantments.

  • cantitō
  • discantō
  • incantō

  • cantrīx

Descendants[edit]
  • → Albanian: këndoj

    • Ido: kantar

    • Neapolitan: cantà

  • Navarro-Aragonese:

  • Old French: chanter
    • French: chanter
    • Bourguignon: chantai
    • tchaintaie (Franche-Comté)

    , canter

    • → English: chant, cant

    • Fala: cantal
    • Galician: cantar
    • Portuguese: cantar
      • Guinea-Bissau Creole: kanta
      • Kabuverdianu: kanta
      • Papiamentu: kanta
  • Old Occitan: chantar, cantar
    • Catalan: cantar
    • Occitan: chantar, cantar
  • Old Spanish: cantar
    • Spanish: cantar
  • Proto-Romanian:
    • Aromanian: cãntu, cãntari
    • Istro-Romanian: cântå
    • Megleno-Romanian: cǫnt
    • Romanian: cânta, cântare
  • Rhaeto-Romance:
    • Friulian: cjantâ, čhantâ
    • Ladin: cianter, cianté, ciantà
    • Romansch: chantar, chanter, cantar
  • Sardinian: cantae, cantai, cantare, cantari
  • Sardinian: cantai
  • Sardinian: cantare
  • Venetian: cantar

Etymology 2[edit]

See the etymology of the main entry.

Participle[edit]

cantō

  1. dative/ablative masculine/neuter singular of cantus
